section.title: What is Wireshark?
section.para: Wireshark is the world's most popular network protocol analyzer. It is used for troubleshooting, analysis, development, and education.

section.title: Bug Fixes
section.para:
The following vulnerabilities have been fixed. See the security advisory for details and a workaround.
The GSM SMS dissector could crash.
Versions affected: 0.99.2 to 1.0.0

The following bugs have been fixed:
Failure to detect/open valid ERF files. (Bug 2359)
Window scaling bug. (Bug 2378)
E212 Mobile network code 3rd digit is not correctly decoded. (Bug 2393)
The BOOTP dissector fails to initialize and display some values. (Bug 2395)
Debian packaging problems. (Bug 2405)
Expert info composite crash for LDAP. (Bug 2407)
Statistics > Multicast Streams are broken. (Bug 2414)
Failed tshark PDML export to file. (Bug 2432)
RTCP MOS fields display wrong values. (Bug 2440)
Ports incorrectly decoded as DPLAY instead of RTP. (Bug 2452)

section.title: New and Updated Features
section.para:
The following features are new (or have been significantly updated) since the last release:
The "About" box finally displays version 1.0.
Wireshark now supports custom columns.
This release includes an experimental Mac OS X package.

section.title: New Protocol Support
section.para: There are no new protocols in this release.

section.title: Updated Protocol Support
section.para: BOOTP, E212, LDAP,

section.title: New and Updated Capture File Support
section.para: Endace ERF

section.title: Getting Wireshark
section.para: Wireshark source code and installation packages are available from the download page on the main web site.

section.title: Vendor-supplied Packages
section.para: Most Linux and Unix vendors supply their own Wireshark packages. You can usually install or upgrade Wireshark using the package management system specific to that platform. A list of third-party packages can be found on the download page on the Wireshark web site.

section.title: File Locations
section.para: Wireshark and TShark look in several different locations for preference files, plugins, SNMP MIBS, and RADIUS dictionaries. These locations vary from platform to platform. You can use About->Folders to find the default locations on your system.

section.title: Known Problems
section.para: Wireshark may appear offscreen on multi-monitor Windows systems. (Bug 553)
Wireshark might make your system disassociate from a wireless network on OS X. (Bug 1315)
Dumpcap might not quit if Wireshark or TShark crashes. (Bug 1419)
Wireshark is unable to decrypt WPA group keys. (Bug 1420)
The BER dissector might infinitely loop. (Bug 1516)
Wireshark can't dynamically update the packet list. This means that host name resolutions above a certain response time threshold won't show up in the packet list. (Bug 1605)
Capture filters aren't applied when capturing from named pipes. (Bug 1814)
Wireshark might freeze when reading from a pipe. (Bug 2082)
Capturing from named pipes might be delayed on Windows. (Bug 2200)
Filtering tshark captures with display filters (-R) no longer works. (Bug 2234)

section.title: Getting Help
section.para: Community support is available on the wireshark-users mailing list. Subscription information and archives for all of Wireshark's mailing lists can be found on the web site.
Commercial support and development services are available from CACE Technologies.
